title: Light  by Margaret Tait - Scottish Poetry Library

last_post.content:
Luz
[Margaret Tait]
¿Dijiste que está hecha de ondas?
Sí, así es.
Me pregunto de qué están hechas las ondas.
Ah, las ondas están hechas de ondas.
Las ondas son lo que son,
destellosidad,
oscilación,
movimiento rítmico que es la esencia inherente de todas las cosas.
En último término, solo hay movimiento,
nada más.
El movimiento que es la luz
sale del sol
y es una cosa tan hermosa
que nada es algo a menos de que esté iluminado por ella.

#poema
https://www.scottishpoetrylibrary.org.uk/poem/light/

I really like this paper: Talking About Large Language Models, by Murray Shanahan

https://www.arxiv-vanity.com/papers/2212.03551/

> A bare-bones LLM doesn’t “really” know anything because all it does, at a fundamental level, is sequence prediction. Sometimes a predicted sequence takes the form of a proposition. But the special relationship propositional sequences have to truth is apparent only to the humans who are asking questions, or to those who provided the data the model was trained on.

The map is even better than it might seem at first glance: the colors are the real colors, the patterns are the real patterns, and the size of the dots is the distance at which each light is visible.

title: Bringing Nanite to Fortnite Battle Royale in Chapter 4

last_post.content:
One detail I found interesting from Epic’s post about porting Fortnite to use Nanite: with Nanite, increasing triangle counts is often cheaper than using an opacity mask because of the added cost of calculations required to support opacity lookups. The same is generally true in the ray tracing world- more triangles is often cheaper than interrupting traversal to do an opacity map lookup or adding more ray intersections from spawning continuation rays in shading.

https://www.unrealengine.com/en-US/tech-blog/bringing-nanite-to-fortnite-battle-royale-in-chapter-4

title: What explains recent tech layoffs, and why should we be worried? | Stanford News

last_post.content:
Layoffs:
- don't save money
- don't improve company performance
- don't increase stock pricess
- destroy trust
- have huge impacts on health, well-being, and income of employees

So why do layoffs? It's a network effect: execs lay people off because other companies are doing it

Stanford Biz School article: https://news.stanford.edu/2022/12/05/explains-recent-tech-layoffs-worried/

Harvard Biz Review:
https://hbr.org/2022/12/what-companies-still-get-wrong-about-layoffs

title: Why I don’t prescribe any preferred pronoun️s

last_post.content:
Hi friends! Seeking some elephantine wisdom with this minor social puzzler:

My workplace is gently pressuring me to add pronouns to my company profile. There as elsewhere, I've just left it blank since I joined.

While I respect others' choices, I feel strongly about having no attachment to the words that other people use when talking about *me*. Claiming otherwise would feel untrue to myself. (Longer reasons, from 2019: https://fogknife.com/2019-02-03-why-i-dont-prescribe-any-preferred-pronoun%EF%B8%8Fs.html)

With the profile in question, I should:

We’re just reinventing it from the grassroots once again. Clients like Ice Cubes and Ivory show previews of Mastodon posts when you include the URL in your quote post. It’s already happening and Mastodon’s official web interface will have to catch up. They lost their chance to define the quote-post on Mastodon by refusing to do it all for highly dubious “safety” reasons. https://mastodon.social/@film_girl/109759044241043089

title: We tried to run a social media site and it was awful

last_post.content:
The FT's Alphaville team shuts down its Mastadon experiment. The reasons are quite telling. https://www.ft.com/content/8d995a24-d77c-4208-a3a6-603d8788ebcd

[edited extract] Here are a few things we learned about why taking responsibility for a social media site is a bad idea:

Compliance, security and reputational risks are substantial and evergrowing in unpredictable ways.

The legal side is all that again times a thousand. Take, for instance, the UK Investigatory Powers Act 2016. Diligent people have spent years figuring out how its imprecise wordings apply to media organisations. Do these same conclusions hold for a sort-of-but-not-really decentralised silo of user generated content?

Do Mastodon server owners wear any responsibility for their users’ defamations? It’s unlikely but, because libel involves judges, not impossible. Again, the value in finding out is outweighed by the cost of finding out.

What about GDPR? Digital Millennium Copyright Act takedowns? Electronic Commerce Regulations? CAN-SPAM? FTAV treats user data with a combination of disinterest and uninterest.

Responsible ownership of a social media network necessitates a bunch of techy stuff that probably wouldn’t trouble a person who doesn’t own a social media network.

After just a month our barely visible Fediverse presence was taking up 160 gigabytes.

Using third-party software builds and cloud services means trusting their terms and conditions.

Sure, Steven Spielberg practically made being a director like being a star, but it’s a testament to his gifts that we’re still talking about many of his works to this day. http://cos.lv/Aw7f50MBuEm

One of our frequent recommendations at @tallpoppy is for folks to have a smol personal website to help them establish an authentic presence for themselves when people search for them. I've had https://leighhoneywell.com for forever and never done anything with it; I just set up a basic-ass linktree-style page on Glitch and am blown away by how easy it was 😻

We usually point folks at squarespace/wix/etc but it's nice to have a more DIY option that also happens to be gratis (for static sites)
And in case you didn't know: open source seeds are already a thing: https://www.opensourceseeds.org/

title: Marijn Sax | What we owe the reader

last_post.content:
Philosopher Marijn Sax explains what is wrong with William MacAskill's 'What We Owe the Future', which focuses on 'longtermism'.

‘Filosoof Marijn Sax legt haarfijn uit wat er mis is met William MacAskills ‘What We Owe the Future’, waarin ‘longtermism’, het idee dat het positief beïnvloeden van de verre toekomst een belangrijke morele prioriteit van onze tijd is, centraal staat.’
https://www.nederlandseboekengids.com/20220125-marijn-sax/ #philosophy #longtermism

I've got a setup that attempts to constrain GPT3's output to rearrangements of trusted texts (sourced by semantic search).¹ Plus, it provides links to sources.

I wanted to start with a low-stakes test. So I hope you enjoy BSing with an AI about what Suffolk clinic to take:

https://suffolklitlab.org/bs

I figure the reach is small enough here I can share a backdoor (will close if need be).

Q: Are you human?
A: shibboleth

----
¹ h/t @simon See https://fedi.simonwillison.net/@simon/109684589298302274

Blender has its own Peertube instance!

It's right here: https://video.blender.org

And across the Fediverse, you can follow their channel here: @blender_channel

That's right, you can watch official Blender channel PeerTube videos within the comfort of Mastodon!

Some people might think, "What's the big deal? Mastodon looks like the Fediverse to me!"

Sure, until it doesn't.

Case in point, this website—which is part of the Fediverse:

https://peertube.tv

What makes Peertube communicate with Mastodon? ActivityPub.

"But people don't use Peertube!"

Wrong. Peertube has 500,000 users, and it's growing.

That's right, Mastodon isn't the only Fediverse game in town.

last_post.content:
5 of 5 stars to Hail Mary by Andy Weir.

I'm not usually a fan of constant flashbacks intermixed with the present, but this story was just too well done.

It was technical enough that I felt like I was learning something without being overbearing. It made me interested in learning more about science, which is cool.

title: Increasing ventilation reduces SARS-CoV-2 airborne transmission in schools: A retrospective cohort study in Italy's Marche region

last_post.content: Would improving ventilation actually help in schools? A study in Italy actually looked at more than 10,000 classrooms and found classrooms equipped with mechanical ventilation systems decreased the relative risk of COVID infection by at least 74% compared to classrooms with only natural ventilation ( https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpubh.2022.1087087/full ). H/T: @linseymarr 15/

title: Semantic wikis as flexible database interfaces for biomedical applications - Scientific Reports

last_post.content:

Finally, this is seemingly also the first proper/major citation of our RDFIO paper we wrote together with a bunch of folks at pharmb.io, KI, @egonw , @vrandecic & Ali King & more 😅 (bunch of citations of the code though, apparently having missing the paper) https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-023-27743-9

Continuing my dive into search vs recsys ( https://gist.github.com/veekaybee/2cf54ebcbd72aa73bfe482f20866c6ef) and came across fighting words, “A recommender system can be viewed as a search ranking system, where the input query is a set of user and contextual information, and the output is a ranked list of items.”
 The wide and deep paper says so and you’re going to have to fight the authors if you disagree 😂 https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/1606.07792

This was fun but slight excruciating project: Mac 30th Anniversary Icons.
68 Mac SVG icons extracted, labelled, and dated from Apple’s 30th anniversary font. If there’s any wrong ones let me know and I’ll get them fixed. https://rknightuk.github.io/mac-30-font-svg/

This is a really interesting study. When Black newborns are cared for by Black physicians, their "clinical penalty" that is the difference in mortality from white newborns is halved.

What's fascinating, if you dive in, is that this is despite the fact that Black physicians tend to have higher caseloads, and also tend to serve more underresourced patients.

Things that make you go hmmmmm...

https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.1913405117

HT: @TheRaDR
